elements.content: The self-assembly of Co(O2CPh)2 with a 2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline (H2dhq) linker has revealed a new two-dimensional cluster-based compound, [Co4(OMe)2(O2CPh)2(dhq)2(MeOH)2] n , which shows spin-canted magnetization and a definite magnetic hysteresis loop.
elements.clean_text: The self-assembly of Co(O2CPh)2 with a 2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline (H2dhq) linker has revealed a new two-dimensional cluster-based compound, [Co4(OMe)2(O2CPh)2(dhq)2(MeOH)2] n , which shows spin-canted magnetization and a definite magnetic hysteresis loop.

elements.content: The use of a 2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline ligand has revealed an unusual cluster-based magnetic layer, [Co4(OMe)2(O2CPh)2(dhq)2(MeOH)2] n , which shows spin-canted magnetization with a definite magnetic hysteresis loop.
elements.clean_text: The use of a 2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline ligand has revealed an unusual cluster-based magnetic layer, [Co4(OMe)2(O2CPh)2(dhq)2(MeOH)2] n , which shows spin-canted magnetization with a definite magnetic hysteresis loop.

elements.content: One of the major challenges in the area of molecular magnetism is the construction of magnetic frameworks that show spontaneous magnetization. In studies of the magnetic properties of magnetic frameworks, the main advantage is the availability of numerous types of structures and topologies, in which a large magnetic anisotropy is produced from a single ion and/or there is a situation where structural distortion can result in the production of multifunctional materials with magnetic properties. Several different strategies have been employed, in attempts to achieve such magnetic entities. However, the design and synthesis of such molecular materials with predictable magnetic properties continues to remain a challenging task because structural factors governing exchange coupling between paramagnetic centers are complex and elusive.
elements.clean_text: One of the major challenges in the area of molecular magnetism is the construction of magnetic frameworks that show spontaneous magnetization. In studies of the magnetic properties of magnetic frameworks, the main advantage is the availability of numerous types of structures and topologies, in which a large magnetic anisotropy is produced from a single ion and/or there is a situation where structural distortion can result in the production of multifunctional materials with magnetic properties. Several different strategies have been employed, in attempts to achieve such magnetic entities. However, the design and synthesis of such molecular materials with predictable magnetic properties continues to remain a challenging task because structural factors governing exchange coupling between paramagnetic centers are complex and elusive.

elements.content: Despite the reports of some molecule-based magnetic metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with a spontaneous magnetization, explorations that are relevant to achieving cluster-based magnetic MOFs are relatively rare in the literature. Concerning the design of hybrid magnetic materials, the selection of an appropriate bridging ligand is of primary importance; the ligands may function as superexchange pathways and building units of structural topology. For a ligand such as 2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline, the two hydroxyl groups and two nitrogen-donor atoms have the capacity to not only connect the metal ions to a multidimensional structure but also shorten the distance between metal ions, which could dominate a magnetic exchange pathway to a significant extent.
elements.clean_text: Despite the reports of some molecule-based magnetic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with a spontaneous magnetization, explorations that are relevant to achieving cluster-based magnetic MOFs are relatively rare in the literature. Concerning the design of hybrid magnetic materials, the selection of an appropriate bridging ligand is of primary importance; the ligands may function as superexchange pathways and building units of structural topology. For a ligand such as 2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline, the two hydroxyl groups and two nitrogen-donor atoms have the capacity to not only connect the metal ions to a multidimensional structure but also shorten the distance between metal ions, which could dominate a magnetic exchange pathway to a significant extent.

elements.content: We herein report on the production of a new cluster-based two-dimensional (2D) layer, [Co4(OMe)2(O2CPh)2(dhq)2(MeOH)2] n (1), produced from the hydrothermal reaction of 2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline and Co(O2CPh)2. This compound not only shows a clustered type of layer structure from the unusual Co4 building units but also exhibits spontaneous magnetization with a definite coercivity.
elements.clean_text: We herein report on the production of a new cluster-based two-dimensional (2D) layer, [Co4(OMe)2(O2CPh)2(dhq)2(MeOH)2] n  (1), produced from the hydrothermal reaction of 2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline and Co(O2CPh)2. This compound not only shows a clustered type of layer structure from the unusual Co4 building units but also exhibits spontaneous magnetization with a definite coercivity.

elements.content: The solvothermal treatment of a mixture of H2dhq and Co(O2CPh)2 in a molar ratio of 1:1 in MeOH at 160 °C in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave for 3 days resulted in the formation of very fine purple crystals of 1 in a yield of 21%.
elements.clean_text: The solvothermal treatment of a mixture of H2dhq and Co(O2CPh)2 in a molar ratio of 1:1 in MeOH at 160 °C in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave for 3 days resulted in the formation of very fine purple crystals of 1 in a yield of 21%.

elements.content: An X-ray crystal structural analysis showed that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. Compound 1 adopts a 2D layer structure that is comprised of a tetranuclear CoII cluster repeating unit (see Figure , top). In each unit, four cobalt ions are located in the same plane, with a zigzag arrangement in which the angle for Co1–Co2–Co2′ is 105.84(2)°. Co1 and Co2 are coordinated in the CoN2O2 tetrahedral and CoNO5 octahedral geometries, respectively. Peripheral ligation around the Co4 unit is provided by two PhCO2 –, two MeO–, two dhq2– ligands, and two MeOH molecules. These two dhq2– ligands function as a η1:η1:η2:η1:μ4 binding mode, which chelates Co1 and Co2′ terminally with one nitrogen atom and one hydroxyl group, respectively, while Co2 and Co2′ are bridged through the other hydroxyl group, resulting in a planar [Co2(OR)2] diamond core with a Co–Co distance of 3.252(1) Å. The MeO– and benzolate groups show η2:μ2 and syn,syn η1:η1:μ2 binding modes, respectively, and bridge Co1 and Co2, resulting in a Co1–Co2 distance of 3.082(1) Å. Moreover, the nitrogen atom in dhq2– is further connected to Co1′ in the next repeating Co4 unit to form a 2D layer, in which each alternative neighboring unit has an angle of 68° in the Co4 plane of the structure (see Figure , bottom). In the crystal, the layers are well isolated, with the shortest interlayer Co···Co distance being 9.879 Å, and no significant interlayer interactions are observed (Figure S1 in the ).
elements.clean_text: An X-ray crystal structural analysis showed that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. Compound 1 adopts a 2D layer structure that is comprised of a tetranuclear CoII cluster repeating unit (see Figure , top). In each unit, four cobalt ions are located in the same plane, with a zigzag arrangement in which the angle for Co1-Co2-Co2' is 105.84(2)°. Co1 and Co2 are coordinated in the CoN2O2 tetrahedral and CoNO5 octahedral geometries, respectively. Peripheral ligation around the Co4 unit is provided by two PhCO2 -, two MeO-, two dhq2- ligands, and two MeOH molecules. These two dhq2- ligands function as a η1:η1:η2:η1:μ4 binding mode, which chelates Co1 and Co2' terminally with one nitrogen atom and one hydroxyl group, respectively, while Co2 and Co2' are bridged through the other hydroxyl group, resulting in a planar [Co2(OR)2] diamond core with a Co-Co distance of 3.252(1) Å. The MeO- and benzolate groups show η2:μ2 and syn,syn η1:η1:μ2 binding modes, respectively, and bridge Co1 and Co2, resulting in a Co1-Co2 distance of 3.082(1) Å. Moreover, the nitrogen atom in dhq2- is further connected to Co1' in the next repeating Co4 unit to form a 2D layer, in which each alternative neighboring unit has an angle of 68° in the Co4 plane of the structure (see Figure , bottom). In the crystal, the layers are well isolated, with the shortest interlayer Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance being 9.879 Å, and no significant interlayer interactions are observed (Figure S1 in the ).

elements.content: (Top) Crystal structure drawing of the Co4 unit of 1. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (bottom) Polyhedral representation of the Co4 cluster-based 2D layer of 1 viewed along the a axis.
elements.clean_text: 1  (Top) Crystal structure drawing of the Co4 unit of 1. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (bottom) Polyhedral representation of the Co4 cluster-based 2D layer of 1 viewed along the a axis.

elements.content: Variable-temperature direct-current (dc) magnetic susceptibility data were collected for complex 1 in the temperature range of 1.8–300 K under an applied field of 1 kOe, and the data (see Figure ) were plotted as χM T vs T. The room-temperature value of χM T was 12.2 emu K mol–1, and χM T decreases with decreasing temperature to a minimum value of 4.1 emu K mol–1 at 20 K, after which it increases, reaching a maximum value of 36.9 emu K mol–1 at 10 K, and then decreases again to 8.4 emu K mol–1 at 1.8 K. The initial χM T could be a result of the depopulation of higher Kramers doublets from the CoII center with an octahedral coordination environment, and antiferromagnetic coupling within the Co4 unit. The steep increases in χM and χM T below 20 K are clearly indicative of spontaneous magnetization, indicating spin-canted antiferromagnetism, which would lead to weak ferromagnetism between the effective spins of adjacent CoII ions. This conclusion was also reinforced by field dependence χM T vs T measurements (see Figure S5 in the ). This magnetic behavior suggests that the Co4 unit is present in a frustrated nonzero spin ground state and that each Co4 unit is coupled antiferromagnetically, as the result of a noncanceled spin alignment, originating from spin-canted magnetism. The observed spin canting may be attributed to the magnetic anisotropy of CoII ions and to an absence structural symmetry at low temperature, as has been previously reported for some spin-canting MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Variable-temperature direct-current (dc) magnetic susceptibility data were collected for complex 1 in the temperature range of 1.8-300 K under an applied field of 1 kOe, and the data (see Figure ) were plotted as χM T vs T. The room-temperature value of χM T was 12.2 emu K mol-1, and χM T decreases with decreasing temperature to a minimum value of 4.1 emu K mol-1 at 20 K, after which it increases, reaching a maximum value of 36.9 emu K mol-1 at 10 K, and then decreases again to 8.4 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K. The initial χM T could be a result of the depopulation of higher Kramers doublets from the CoII center with an octahedral coordination environment, and antiferromagnetic coupling within the Co4 unit. The steep increases in χM and χM T below 20 K are clearly indicative of spontaneous magnetization, indicating spin-canted antiferromagnetism, which would lead to weak ferromagnetism between the effective spins of adjacent CoII ions. This conclusion was also reinforced by field dependence χM T vs T measurements (see Figure S5 in the ). This magnetic behavior suggests that the Co4 unit is present in a frustrated nonzero spin ground state and that each Co4 unit is coupled antiferromagnetically, as the result of a noncanceled spin alignment, originating from spin-canted magnetism. The observed spin canting may be attributed to the magnetic anisotropy of CoII ions and to an absence structural symmetry at low temperature, as has been previously reported for some spin-canting MOFs.

elements.content: Plots of χM T vs T for 1 in an applied field of 1 kOe from 1.8 to 300 K and FC/ZFC magnetization for 1 at an applied field of 100 Oe (inset).
elements.clean_text: 2  Plots of χM T vs T for 1 in an applied field of 1 kOe from 1.8 to 300 K and FC/ZFC magnetization for 1 at an applied field of 100 Oe (inset).

elements.content: To further investigate the possible phase transition suggested by the increase in the χM T curve, zero-field-cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) magnetization were measured from 2.0 to 50 K under 100 Oe. As can be seen from the inset in Figure , the ZFC magnetization shows a broad peak at 10 K and diverges from FC magnetization at about 12 K. This type of divergence reveals a possible transition from a paramagnetic state to either a long-range-ordered, spin-glass, or superparamagnetic state. The hysteresis loops at 2.0, 3.0, 6.0, 8.0, and 10 K and isothermal magnetization M(H) at 2.0 K with a field of up to 70 kOe were measured, and the data are represented in Figures and S6 in the , respectively. A hysteresis loop can be clearly seen, even at 8 K. The coercivity fields and remnant magnetizations are H C = 4.77, 3.28, 2.43, and 1.79 kOe and M R = 0.523, 0.519, 0.515, and 0.513 Nβ (β = Bohr magneton) at 2.0, 3.0, 6.0, and 8.0 K, respectively. At 2.0 K, the magnetization shows a step at around 1300 Oe, which then increases slowly to 2.12 Nβ at 70 kOe, which is far from the saturated magnetization value M S = 13 Nβ but close to a CoII spin of 2.17 Nβ resulting from a Kramers S = 1/2 and average g = 13/3. The existence of a step in the magnetization at low field is indicative of metamagnetism in 1 (Figure S6 in the ), and we attribute this behavior to the depression of the antiparallel configuration between spin-canting layers.
elements.clean_text: To further investigate the possible phase transition suggested by the increase in the χM T curve, zero-field-cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) magnetization were measured from 2.0 to 50 K under 100 Oe. As can be seen from the inset in Figure , the ZFC magnetization shows a broad peak at 10 K and diverges from FC magnetization at about 12 K. This type of divergence reveals a possible transition from a paramagnetic state to either a long-range-ordered, spin-glass, or superparamagnetic state. The hysteresis loops at 2.0, 3.0, 6.0, 8.0, and 10 K and isothermal magnetization M(H) at 2.0 K with a field of up to 70 kOe were measured, and the data are represented in Figures  and S6 in the , respectively. A hysteresis loop can be clearly seen, even at 8 K. The coercivity fields and remnant magnetizations are H C = 4.77, 3.28, 2.43, and 1.79 kOe and M R = 0.523, 0.519, 0.515, and 0.513 Nβ (β = Bohr magneton) at 2.0, 3.0, 6.0, and 8.0 K, respectively. At 2.0 K, the magnetization shows a step at around 1300 Oe, which then increases slowly to 2.12 Nβ at 70 kOe, which is far from the saturated magnetization value M S = 13 Nβ but close to a CoII spin of 2.17 Nβ resulting from a Kramers S = 1/2 and average g = 13/3. The existence of a step in the magnetization at low field is indicative of metamagnetism in 1 (Figure S6 in the ), and we attribute this behavior to the depression of the antiparallel configuration between spin-canting layers.

elements.content: Magnetization vs field hysteresis loop measurements of 1 at the indicated temperatures at a scan rate of 0.03 T s–1.
elements.clean_text: 3  Magnetization vs field hysteresis loop measurements of 1 at the indicated temperatures at a scan rate of 0.03 T s-1.

elements.content: Furthermore, alternating-current (ac) susceptibilities under dc (H dc = 0 Oe) and ac (H ac = 3.5 Oe) fields were measured from 2 to 20 K with a frequency from 10 to 10 000 Hz. The results show strong peaks in both the in-phase (χM′) and out-of-phase (χM″) parts. Upon decreasing temperature, the in-phase signals χM′ behave similarly to the ZFC curves; i.e., they increase abruptly at around 12 K, reach a maximum at about 11.5 K, and then decrease slowly toward zero (Figure S7 in the ). The out-of-phase signals χM″ increase steadily to a maximum of approximately 11.5–9.5 K (see Figure ). The dχM′/dT curves all show peaks at T C = 11.6 K, consistent with the dc measurements. While this behavior would not be expected to occur for true three-dimensionally ordered magnets, it is consistent with a spin-glass magnet. The peak temperatures of χM′ can be measured by the parameter ϕ = (ΔT p/T p)/Δ(log f) = 0.003, indicating spin-glass behavior. Moreover, the specific heat was measured under a zero applied field of 1.8–20 K (see Figure S8 in the ). A shoulder peak was observed at around 12 K, which is in good agreement with the occurrence of a spontaneous magnetization temperature, T C, deduced from the ac susceptibility signal. This observation from specific heat measurements may due to spin-glass freezing. Moreover, the ac data were collected using the same sample that had been heated at 350 °C for 2 h (see Figure S9 in the ), which shows the absence of out-of phase signals and changing in-phase signals, excluding the contribution of the behavior of cobalt(II) oxide.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, alternating-current (ac) susceptibilities under dc (H dc = 0 Oe) and ac (H ac = 3.5 Oe) fields were measured from 2 to 20 K with a frequency from 10 to 10000 Hz. The results show strong peaks in both the in-phase (χM') and out-of-phase (χM") parts. Upon decreasing temperature, the in-phase signals χM' behave similarly to the ZFC curves; i.e., they increase abruptly at around 12 K, reach a maximum at about 11.5 K, and then decrease slowly toward zero (Figure S7 in the ). The out-of-phase signals χM" increase steadily to a maximum of approximately 11.5-9.5 K (see Figure ). The dχM'/dT curves all show peaks at T C = 11.6 K, consistent with the dc measurements. While this behavior would not be expected to occur for true three-dimensionally ordered magnets, it is consistent with a spin-glass magnet. The peak temperatures of χM' can be measured by the parameter ϕ = (ΔT p/T p)/Δ(log f) = 0.003, indicating spin-glass behavior. Moreover, the specific heat was measured under a zero applied field of 1.8-20 K (see Figure S8 in the ). A shoulder peak was observed at around 12 K, which is in good agreement with the occurrence of a spontaneous magnetization temperature, T C, deduced from the ac susceptibility signal. This observation from specific heat measurements may due to spin-glass freezing. Moreover, the ac data were collected using the same sample that had been heated at 350 °C for 2 h (see Figure S9 in the ), which shows the absence of out-of phase signals and changing in-phase signals, excluding the contribution of the behavior of cobalt(II) oxide.

elements.content: Plots of χM″ vs temperature for a powdered sample of complex 1 in a 3.5 G ac field. The data were collected in an ac field oscillating at the indicated frequency.
elements.clean_text: 4  Plots of χM" vs temperature for a powdered sample of complex 1 in a 3.5 G ac field. The data were collected in an ac field oscillating at the indicated frequency.

elements.content: In conclusion, we describe the preparation of a new cluster-based 2D layer with an unusual repeating unit of [Co4(OMe)2(O2CPh)2(dhq)2(MeOH)2] n , prepared using a 2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline ligand (H2dhq), which exhibits spin-glass behavior resulting from spin-canting magnetic interactions. It thus appears that the H2dhq ligand utilized here has the potential for generating novel frameworks with promising structural features and properties. Furthermore, these results provide strong justification for further studies of H2dhq and derivatives thereof with other transition metals and could lead to the development of even more interesting magnetic MOFs.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we describe the preparation of a new cluster-based 2D layer with an unusual repeating unit of [Co4(OMe)2(O2CPh)2(dhq)2(MeOH)2] n , prepared using a 2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline ligand (H2dhq), which exhibits spin-glass behavior resulting from spin-canting magnetic interactions. It thus appears that the H2dhq ligand utilized here has the potential for generating novel frameworks with promising structural features and properties. Furthermore, these results provide strong justification for further studies of H2dhq and derivatives thereof with other transition metals and could lead to the development of even more interesting magnetic MOFs.

elements.content: Satisfactory elemental analytical data found (calcd) for C17H16Co2N2O6 (1): C, 44.14 (44.18); H, 3.60 (3.49); N, 6.28 (6.06). Crystal data for 1: C17H16Co2N2O6, M = 462.18, monoclinic, space group P21/c, a = 14.2780(7) Å, b = 11.1546(6) Å, c = 11.3505(6) Å, β = 104.082(3)°, V = 1753.42(16) Å3, Z = 4, T = 150(2) K, R (R w ) = 0.0433 (0.1033).

metadata.title:
Spin-Canting Magnetization
in an Unusual Co4 Cluster-Based Layer Compound from a 2,3-Dihydroxyquinoxaline
Ligand
